description: A stroke is an acquired injury to the brain caused by either reduced blood supply (i.e., ischemia) leading to infarction (necrosis of brain tissue)(1) or a hemorrhage within the parenchyma of the brain(2,31)

Constraint-induced  movement therapy (CIMT) is a therapeutic intervention for the upper or lower extremity.(3) CIMT is based on learned nonuse, which describes the phenomenon observed in humans (and animals) in which an individual with a hemiparesis feels the negative consequences of the increased effort required to use the affected limb while simultaneously feeling positively reinforced for using compensatory strategies with the unaffected limb.(3) The result is a learned behavior of limb nonuse despite the possibility that the involved limb might physically still be able to perform purposeful motor movements.CIMT was developed to counteract the effects of learned nonuse in patients with acquired neurological damage to an upper extremity(3,4)

Traditional CIMT involves restraining the unaffected (or less-affected)  upper extremity 90% of waking hours over the course of 2–6 weeks while performing daily 6-hour training sessions with the affected upper extremity.(3) Due to the intensity of CIMT protocols, it has been linked to poor compliance and reimbursement restrictions(3)

In response to CIMT limitations, modified CIMT (mCIMT) has been adopted as a variation of CIMT that uses a less intensive protocol. A typical mCIMT shortens the training sessions to 30 minutes per day, 3 times per week and reduces the restraint time of the nonaffected extremity to ˂ 6 hours per day(45)

Although there is some variance in the literature regarding specific protocols and related results, CIMT has been found to be effective during acute rehabilitation (as early as 0–3 months post stroke)through chronic stroke (15–21  months or greater post stroke) and is most effective with patients who have less severe motor deficits (e.g., ability to initiate movement and with at least 20° of wrist extension and 10° of digit extension)(3) ICD-10  codes
reimbursement: Reimbursement for therapy will depend on insurance contract coverage. Despite the growing body of literature supporting the use of CIMT in survivors of stroke with upper extremity impairment, few private insurance companies reimburse for 6 hours of skilled intervention 5 days per week; Medicare/Medicaid does not reimburse for CIMT(5)

mCIMT is more likely to be reimbursable.(5) Some studies have shown mCIMT to be as effective as CIMT(3)  –It is important to note that there is no standardized or “best practice” protocol for mCIMT. Many research studies use the term mCIMT; however, there is variability in the frequency and intensity of these programs, so it is difficult for researchers to compare results across studies, for therapists to devise an effective treatment plan, and for payers to provide appropriate reimbursement. Everyone involved in treatment by CIMT/mCIMT, including patients, would benefit from a clearly defined mCIMT protocol(28)
presentation signs and symptoms: Each survivor of stroke presents differently as a result of the specific location and severity of the stroke.(2) Symptoms of acute stroke appear suddenly(6)

Common presenting signs/symptoms of stroke (many of these deficits will persist following the stroke) –Cognitive impairment(1,2) –Dizziness and vertigo –Dysphagia (swallowing impairment)(1,2) -For additional information on dysphagia following stroke, see the series of Clinical Reviews on this topic –Impairment of gait(1) –Motor weakness,(1,2) typically unilateral –Nausea and vomiting(1) –Perceptual impairment(1,2) –Sensory loss(1,2) –Speech and language difficulties(1,2) -For additional information on speech and language impairments following stroke, see the series of Clinical Reviews on these topics –Syncope(1) –Tinnitus(1) –Visual impairment(1,2) -For additional information on assessment and treatment of patients with visual impairments, see  Clinical Review…Visual Dysfunction: Occupational Therapy  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708963 –Urinary incontinence(2) -For additional information on assessment and treatment of patients with urinary incontinence, see  Clinical Review… Incontinence, Urinary (Occupational Therapy)  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T709021

Common sequelae of left or right hemisphere stroke –Left hemisphere – right hemiparesis/hemiplegia (one-sided weakness or paralysis); right hemisphere – left hemiparesis/ hemiplegia(3) -Upper and lower extremity might both be impaired(7) -Ranges from mild weakness to complete paralysis(3) -Can cause abnormal muscle tone, which might impact the patient’s ability to perform ADLs, bed mobility, and transfers -For additional information on assessment and treatment of upper extremity impairment, see  Clinical Review…Stroke: Upper Extremity  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708721 –Additional sequelae of left hemisphere stroke -Aphasia/communication deficits(3) -Apraxia/motor planning deficits(3) –Additional sequelae of right hemisphere stroke -Visual field deficits/spatial neglect(3) -For information on assessment and treatment of unilateral neglect, see  Clinical Review…Stroke Rehabilitation: Unilateral Neglect  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708897 -Cognitive impairments such as poor judgment/insight, impulsivity, and reduced memory(3) Causes, Pathogenesis, & Risk Factors
contraindications precautions to test: Stroke survivors will have different patterns of deficits as a result of the specific size, extent, and location of lesion; occupational therapy evaluations for survivors of stroke should use a client-centered  approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(4,13) –A client-centered  approach is based on the following principles -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about his or her occupational functioning(4) -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes(4) -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent(4) -Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc.(4)  -When the patient is able to define the problems that he or she would like to work on, the patient also becomes the problem solver(4) -The patient should evaluate his or her own performance and set personal goals(4)

pathogenesis: Ischemic strokes: prolonged lack of blood flow to brain cells (neurons, glial, and endothelial cells) results in infarction ofthese cells(37)–The total arrest of circulation to the area of the cerebrum supplied by the cerebral artery results in irreversible cellulardamage within minutes; the core area of this damage is referred to as the ischemic penumbra(9)-In addition to the death of cells in the penumbra, there is also potentially reversible damage to surrounding brain cells;immediate medical intervention is the best hope for reversing this damage(9)-Ischemic strokes also cause cerebral edema, which elevates intracranial pressure and might lead to worseningneurological deficits, loss of consciousness, coma, and/or death(9)–For thrombotic ischemic strokes, a critical degree of atherosclerosis causes the complete or almost complete blockage ofblood flow to a local area of the brain(8)–For embolic ischemic strokes, the blockage of blood flow is a result of a clot forming elsewhere in the body, breaking off,and travelling to and lodging in a vessel of the brain(8)
Hemorrhagic strokes: hemorrhage in the brain leads to edema, mass effect, and midline shift; for patients with extensivehemorrhage with significant cerebral edema and herniation(6)
In survivors of stroke, CNS damage can result in widespread morbidities (e.g., visual impairment, speech impairment,sensory changes, paresis) leading to functional deficits(4)
risk factors: Advanced age (risk doubles each decade after age 55)(10)
Sex (more common in women than men)(10)–Use of birth control pills and pregnancy might increase risk of stroke in women(10)
History of stroke, MI, or transient ischemic attack (TIA)(1,10)
Carotid or other artery disease (including peripheral artery disease)(10)
Atrial fibrillation or other heart disease(1,10)
Geographical location (in the United States, strokes are more common in the Southeast)(10)
Socioeconomic factors (there is some evidence that strokes are more common among persons of low income)(10)

overall contraindications precautions: An occupational therapy assessment should include the patient and family/friends as appropriate; including the patient’s familial and social network in the rehabilitation process might assist in the patient’s psychosocial recovery

Be sensitive to pain  in survivors of stroke; some patients will have hypersensitivity to pain and others will have hyposensitivity; ensure that the patient has a reliable means of communicating pain throughout evaluation and treatment(9,11,12)
Refer patient to emergency services or immediately alert nursing/admitting physician if the patient exhibits signs/symptoms of a progressing, recurrent, or new stroke(3)

Risk of DVT is significantly increased in patients with hemiplegia; assess for signs of DVT (e.g., redness, warmth, pain, tenderness, swelling) and refer to physician urgently if these symptoms are present(2,9)

Aspiration pneumonia can occur in survivors of stroke who have dysphagia; verify and adhere to swallowing guidelines and swallowing order on file prior to administering any food or drink. Refer to physician if patient complains of difficulty swallowing, persistent wet cough, or fever(2)

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls. Follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Educate family and caregivers about fall risk and fall-prevention strategies
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/Plan

contraindications precautions to examina: Stroke survivors will have different patterns of deficits as a result of the specific size, extent, and location of lesion; occupational therapy evaluations for survivors of stroke should use a client-centered  approach to most effectively evaluate deficits and needs(4,13) –A client-centered  approach is based on the following principles -The patient is uniquely qualified to make decisions about his or her occupational functioning(4) -The patient should have an active role in determining goals and desired outcomes(4) -The patient-therapist  relationship should be interdependent(4) -Evaluation and treatment should focus on the patient’s culture, roles, interests, etc.(4)  -When the patient is able to define the problems that he or she would like to work on, the patient also becomes the problem solver(4) -The patient should evaluate his or her own performance and set personal goals(4)

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Review medical chart and physician reports to ascertain information about the size, location, type, and extent of the stroke -Was the stroke ischemic or hemorrhagic? If ischemic, was it embolic or thrombotic? -What were the presenting signs and symptoms of the stroke, and how have they progressed since presentation? -Have there been any complications?

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management of acute stroke involves determining the cause and location of a stroke with imaging tests such as MRI and CT scan, preventing further brain damage/progression of the stroke and secondary medical complications, and treating acute neurological symptoms(3) Treatment for acute ischemic stroke focuses on restoration of blood flow to the area affected by the blockage to reduce neuronal damage(3) Blood thinners to improve blood flow through blocked vessels(3) Thrombolytic drugs (such as tissue plasminogen activator [t-PA])  are used to break up a clot and immediately restore blood flow (limiting permanent damage); however, these must be administered within a specific number of hours after stroke onset(2,3) to be safe and effective t-PA has been shown to reduce disability in patients appropriate for its use(2) Hemorrhagic strokes are managed acutely by stopping the bleeding, controlling intracranial pressure, preventing rebleeding and vasospasm, and maintaining cerebral perfusion(3) Surgical intervention for stroke might involve craniotomy or endovascular interventions in the acute phase for evacuation of large intracerebral hematoma or due to swelling from increased intracranial pressure(2,3) Nonpharmacologic medical interventions for stroke include above-the-knee  elastic stockings or pneumatic boots to prevent pulmonary emboli(1) Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended for patients with carotid territory stroke and 7090% ipsilateral carotid stenosis(1,2) Physicians might manage spasticity with phenol or botulinum toxin injections(2)
course of treatment.medications: Determine what medications the physician has prescribed; are they being taken? Blood thinners or antiplatelet therapy might be utilized for patients with ischemic stroke(1,2,3) Medications to control blood pressure/hypertension(1) Warfarin (an anticoagulant) might be prescribed for patients with embolic stroke and/or atrial fibrillation.(2) Other medications might also be prescribed (e.g., Apixaban) for patients with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation to prevent recurrent stroke(32) Patients with history of stroke might be placed on combination of an angiotensin-converting  enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and thiazidetype  diuretic to prevent recurrent stroke(1) Antispasticity medications might be prescribed for patients with muscle spasticity(2) Stool softeners or laxatives for patients with bowel dysfunction(4) Anticholinergic medications for urinary incontinence(2) SSRIs for poststroke depression(2)
diagnostic tests completed: Diagnostic tests completed:  Usual tests for this condition are the following:
Diagnostic imaging (MRI, CT scan, chest X-ray, etc.)(1,2)
Blood work (CBC, platelets, PT[INR], PTT, BUN, creatinine, glucose, urinalysis)(1)
Cardiac tests for suspected embolic etiology
Evaluation of hypercoagulable states in select individuals (e.g., young patients, patients with no risk factors)(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help The American Heart Association/American Stroke Association stroke rehabilitation guidelines state that the effectiveness ofacupuncture for hemiplegic shoulder pain is uncertain,there is insufficient evidence for its effectiveness in increasing motor recovery or mobility, and they do not recommend its use for improving ADLs and upper extremity activity. However, the guidelines state that acupuncture may be considered as an adjunctive treatment for dysphagia(51)
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Are there any factors that affect the patient’s muscle tone, arousal, or ability to participate in therapy?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart (when relevant) to document location and nature of symptoms
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling) -Specifically note the nature of symptoms associated with the impaired upper extremity
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) (or other nonverbal pain scale for patients with aphasia, reduced arousal, or cognitive deficits) or 010 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much) -Some patients will have pain associated with the sequelae of stroke; however, other survivors of stroke might have impaired sensation of pain(1) -Strokes affecting the ventral posterolateral thalamus and spinothalamic system can result in central poststroke (thalamic) pain(9) -This pain is often described as constant, severe, and burning, with intermittent sharp pains(9) -Touch, pressure, temperature, and/or noise might trigger pain response(9) -Patients with severe pain from stroke might have difficulty participating in rehabilitation programs(9)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient might be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., headache, edema, signs of new stroke) -Seizures might develop as a complication of stroke(2,9) -Hydrocephalus (accumulation of excess cerebrospinal fluid [CSF] within the cerebral cavity) can occur following hemorrhagic stroke; symptoms include headache, nausea, vomiting, visual disturbance, and increasing lethargy and/or ataxia; refer to physician immediately if these symptoms are noted or reported(9) -Risk of DVT is significantly increased in patients with hemiplegia; assess for signs of DVT (e.g., redness, warmth, pain, tenderness, swelling) and refer to physician urgently if these symptoms are present(2,9) -Aspiration pneumonia can occur in survivors of stroke who have dysphagia; refer to physician if patient complains of difficulty swallowing, persistent wet cough, and/or fever(2)
history of present illness.respiratory status: Note respiratory status -Pulmonary function often is impaired in survivors of stroke(9) -Does the patient require supplemental oxygen? Tracheostomy tube, nasal cannula, or breathing mask? -Does the patient become short of breath? If so, when? Standing? Walking? With exercise?Depression is common among survivors of stroke(2,9,11) -Other psychosocial issues that occur in survivors of stroke include pseudobulbar affect (emotional lability), apathy, euphoria, isolation, and social withdrawal(9) -Briefly assess psychosocial status, inquiring about symptoms of depression and other emotional distress; refer to psychiatrist, psychologist, or social worker when appropriate -The Beck Depression Inventory (BDI) is a useful tool for screening patients for depression(9)Note patient’s hearing abilities -Does the patient speak loudly even in close, quiet conversational environments? -If the patient appears to have impaired hearing, refer to audiology for further workup Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning (e.g., neglect, aphasia) ? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Previous history of same/similar diagnosis Is there a prior history of stroke or TIA? If so, what deficits were preexisting? Is there history of other cardiovascular disease, such as hypertension or arterial stenosis? Does the patient have a history of previous impairment of the upper extremity from stroke, neurological disease, or injury? Conditions that limited upper extremity mobility prior to stroke usually are exclusion criteria for CIMT
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, and orthopedic disorders
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he/she might be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Vocation/avocation and associated repetitive behaviors, if any -What are the patient’s occupation and role within his or her family?(9) -Which is the patient’s dominant hand? Is it the affected side? -Is he or she currently employed? -Is the patient hoping to return to work? -To what extent is arm and hand use required for the patient’s job? -Survivors of stroke who wish to return to work may need a full vocational assessment -What activities, hobbies, etc., did the patient enjoy prior to the stroke? -To what extent is arm and hand use required for the patient’s hobbies? -A patient/caregiver interview might be helpful to gain insight into the patient’s hobbies, family/community roles, interests, prior work status, and home responsibilities -Consider psychospiritual needs and desires such as prayer and/or meditation, as many survivors of stroke benefit from incorporation of some type of psychospiritual activity(14) -Refer to hospital chaplain, recreational therapist, or social worker for additional assessment and recommendations for appropriate activities(14)
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: What current assistive or adaptive equipment is available to the patient at home? Can it still be utilized based on patient’s current level of functioning? Did the patient use an ambulatory assistive device held in the affected hand? -Document both high-  and low-tech  adaptations and equipment
social and occupational history.living environment: Living environment -Who is the patient’s primary caregiver?(13) -The patient’s primary caregiver plays an important role in utilization of rehabilitation services and overall outcomes of therapy(13,15) -Education of the caregiver as well as a contract or agreement to assist in facilitation of CIMT might be necessary as it is labor intensive and difficult without caregiver participation -Patients with live-in  caregivers who receive outside assistance are most likely to utilize both inpatient and outpatient therapy(15) -If the patient has no caregiver or the patient’s caregiver is not receiving guidance or assistance with the patient’s care, refer to social worker or case management(13) -With whom does the patient live (e.g., spouse/partner, parents, children, siblings, grandparents, caregivers)? -Are there pets in the home? -Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; are any modifications necessary?(9) -Inquire about the levels of the home, including stairs, numbers of floors, etc. -A home visit might be beneficial to provide functional and realistic environmental modifications around the house

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting.)  Measures described below are specific to assessment of survivors of stroke prior to initiating CIMT; for additional information on assessment and treatment of upper extremity poststroke, see  Clinical Review…Stroke: Upper Extremity  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708721; for an overview of all areas of occupational therapy assessment poststroke, see  Clinical Review…Stroke Rehabilitation: Occupational Therapy – an Overview  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number: T708955; also see series of Clinical Reviews  on specific areas of stroke rehabilitation
relevant tests and measures.assistive and adaptive devices: Assess the patient’s need for and/or use of assistive and adaptive devices; incorrect use of devices can increase risk of falls –Observe patient’s use of appropriate devices with each hand individually and with both hands together as able –Mobility aids -Cane -Walker -Wheelchair -Crutches -Hemi-walker -Ankle-foot  orthoses (AFOs) –Toileting and showering equipment -Grab bars next to the toilet/in the shower or bath -Bedside commode -A urinal at bedside  -Raised toilet seat -Elevated footrest at the toilet -Tub or shower bench –ADL/IADL aids -Reachers -Personal digital assistant (PDA) -Large-print  reading material -Adaptive/ergonomic computer/mouse/keyboard -Text-to-speech  software -Adaptive cooking equipment
relevant tests and measures.balance: Balance and postural control often is impaired in survivors of stroke(9) –Evaluate static and dynamic balance in sitting and standing as well as functionally during ADL tasks involving weight shifting(9) –The severity of the balance impairment might exclude a patient from participation in CIMT -The patient must have adequate balance for dynamic mobility with unaffected arm restrained -The need for an ambulatory aid could likely exclude the patient from participating in CIMT -Clinicians must use sound judgment to decide if modification or exclusion of a patient from CIMT is preferable, as the specific symptoms of stroke must be considered in each case -Ipsilateral pushing (also referred to as pusher syndrome or contraversive pushing) might occur after stroke.(9)Since patients with pusher syndrome will actively push with the stronger extremities toward the hemiparetic side, the patient’s ability to balance during functional activities such as standing, transferring, and walking is impaired.(9)Such impairment might exclude the patient from participation in any form of CIMT -For additional information on pusher syndrome, see  Clinical Review…Pusher Syndrome  ; CINAHL Topic IDT709133
cardiorespiratory function and endurance: Refer to physician orders regarding cardiac and exercise limitations(9)
Assess heart rate, blood pressure, O 2saturation, and respiratory rate regularly pre/during/post activity(9)
relevant tests and measures.circulation: Assess pulse bilaterally; note any discrepancies or abnormalitiesBed mobility and transfers should be assessed to determine the amount of assistance needed for the patient to perform each activity –Test static and dynamic activitiesa measurement of mobility; includes tasks such as standing from a seated position, walking, turning, stopping, and sitting down, all of which are important for independent mobility(53) –FIM – an 18-item,  7-level  ordinal scale assessing functional mobility, ADLs, language skills, and cognition(54)
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Observe patient’s gait and ability to climb stairs (assisted or unassisted) –Note use of braces or ambulatory aids for walking(2) -The need for an ambulatory aid could likely exclude the patient from participating in CIMT –If the patient presents with impaired gait, referral to physical therapy might be appropriate –If applicable, assess wheelchair mobility –Safety of walking while arm constrainedAssess joint integrity and mobility(9) –Assess upper extremity active and passive range of motion (AROM/PROM)(9) -Note hyper-  and hypomobility as well as soft tissue changes such as swelling, inflammation, and restriction at the shoulder, elbow, and wrist(9) –Shoulder subluxation is common among survivors of stroke(2,9) -Assess gently, as the shoulder might be very painful(7) -Early ROM exercises and sling might help prevent subluxation of the shoulder;(7)however, if a sling is required, it excludes the patient from participating in CIMT  –Joint contractures and deformities can develop at the shoulder, elbow, and/or wrist in survivors of stroke; often occur in patients with significant spasticity(7) -For patients with spasticity, assess for appropriateness of assistive equipment and splints to prevent contractures(7)Assess fine and gross motor function of both upper extremities; note differences between the affected (or more-affected)  limb and the unaffected (or less-affected)  limb –Patient should be able to initiate movement and with at least 20° of wrist extension and 10° of digit extension to participate in CIMT –Note through how much of the available ROM the patient can move and if it is isolated movement or not; describe the quality of the movement –Initially after a stroke, muscles usually are flaccid; over the first few weeks following the stroke, patients might experience increase in muscle tone and spasticity in affected upper and lower extremity(7,9) -Spasticity is most commonly in an extensor pattern; however, flexion patterns of spasticity also occur(7) -Obligatory synergy patterns might emerge with spasticity; this can result in the inability to use a limb segment without producing movement in the remainder of the limb (e.g., attempting to produce elbow flexion results in shoulder flexion, abduction, and external rotation)(9) -Observe voluntary movement patterns bilaterally; note abnormalities as well as differences between the affected and unaffected limbs(9) –Abnormal reflexes are common in survivors of stroke; the extent and combination of abnormal reflexes vary among patients as well as according to the specific stage of recovery(9) -Hyporeflexia is observed initially while muscles are flaccid(9) -Hyperreflexia occurs when spasticity begins to emerge(9) -Patients might demonstrate clonus, clasp-knife response, and positive Babinski reflex(9) –Apraxia (impairment of motor programming) is common in survivors of stroke who have experienced a lesion of the premotor frontal cortex, left inferior parietal lobe, and/or the corpus callosum(9) –Patients with decreased dexterity might be more significantly impaired in their ability to complete ADLs -It is important to inquire about and document the patient’s hand dominance prior to the stroke; patients who have hemiplegia on their dominant side will have greater reaching deficits than patients with nondominant hemiplegia(9) -Observe manual dexterity; serial opposition or rapidly touching each finger to thumb in succession –ABILHAND(16) -Questionnaire designed to assess the patient’s perceived difficulty in performing everyday tasks(16) -Measures outcomes and assists with goal planning(16) -Rated as adequate reliability and validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Action Research Arm Test (ARAT)(16) -Standardized assessment of arm motor function in terms of grasp, grip, pinch, and gross motor ability(16) -Rated as excellent reliability and validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Arm Motor Ability Test (AMAT)(4,16) -Standardized assessment that evaluates functional ability and quality of movement of the arm; 28 tasks including eating with a spoon, opening a jar, tying a shoelace, and using the telephone(4) -Appropriate for patients with mild-moderate  motor impairment; some research studies have found that the AMAT might underestimate deficits in patients with severe motor impairment(16) -Rated as adequate reliability and excellent validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Chedoke Arm and Hand Activity Inventory (CAHAI)(16) -Standardized assessment for upper extremity following stroke(16) -Test items include performing ADL activities(16) -Rated as excellent reliability and validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Functional Test for the Hemiparetic Upper Extremity(4)  -Assesses arm and hand function through 17 hierarchical functional tasks such as folding a sheet, screwing in a light bulb, stabilizing a jar, and zipping a zipper(4) –Fugl-Meyer  Assessment (FMA)(5,17) -Standardized assessment of upper extremity and lower motor and sensory impairment(17) -Sensory function might be used as a predictor of long-term  outcomes with CIMT(18) –Jebsen Test of Hand Function(4) -Contains seven activities, including writing, turning over stacked index cards, simulated eating, moving empty and weighted cans, and picking up small objects(4) –Manual Ability Measure (MAM-36)(4) -Thirty-six  item self-reported  outcome measure of commonly performed upper extremity tasks –Modified Ashworth Scale (mAS)(9) -Severity of spasticity can be graded on the mAS(9) –Motor Activity Log (MAL)(16) -Developed to measure the improvement of learned nonuse as well as the use of the impaired upper extremity in ADLs poststroke(16) -Structured, scripted interview format(16) -Rated as adequate reliability and excellent validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Motor Assessment Scale (MAS)(4,16) -MAS is a standardized assessment designed for use with survivors of stroke; eight items in the full assessment, three of which assess upper limb functioning (upper arm function, hand and advanced hand movements)(16) -Rated as excellent reliability and validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Upper Extremity Performance Test for the Elderly (TEMPA)(4) -Upper extremity assessment composed of nine standardized tasks; assesses tasks both bilaterally and unilaterally(4) –Wolf Motor Function Test (WMFT)(16) -Standardized assessment developed to be sensitive to motor functioning of patients with mild-moderate stroke as well as examine the effects of CIMT(16) -Assists with distinguishing higher-functioning patients from lower-functioning  patients with subacute stroke(16) -Seventeen subtests with tasks ranging in difficulty from simple to complex(16) -Rated as adequate reliability and validity per review of the literature on upper extremity assessments(16) –Nine-hole  peg test for fine motor control(19)
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Assess muscle strength –Manual muscle testing (MMT) to evaluate strength in both upper extremities, including the shoulder, elbow, forearm, wrist, and fingers; do not perform MMT on muscles with contractures or muscles with tone and coordination issues(9) -Distal muscles typically exhibit greater strength deficits than proximal muscles(9) -Diffuse muscle atrophy and weakness result from prolonged immobility and inactivity(9) –Dynamometer to evaluate hand strength bilaterally –Assess grip force in functional tasks –Assess pinch strength –Motricity Index(4) -Measures limb strength impairments with weighted ordinal scale(4)
observation inspection palpation includi: Perception of spatial relationships, textures, and shapes frequently is impaired in survivors of stroke(7)
Recommend referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  if symptoms of visual disturbances are noted during
relevant tests and measures.arousal attention cognition: Note patient’s ability to communicate and level of arousal as well as memory, attention, problem solving, and orientation to person, place, time, and situation –A brief cognitive assessment such as the Mini-Mental  State Examination (MMSE)(52) is an appropriate screen for cognitive impairment in survivors of stroke –Patients with right hemisphere strokes might demonstrate left-sided  inattention/left neglect -Left neglect can result in injury to the left side, as the patient is unaware of his or her own left limbs;(3) neglect should be addressed prior to CIMT, as it precludes CIMTT708897 –For patients with cognitive impairment, referral to neuropsychology might be appropriate for extensive assessment and input regarding cognitive intervention(2) –Refer to speech-language  pathology reports regarding speech, language, or cognitive-linguistic  impairments(9) –For information on assessment and treatment of cognitive deficits following stroke, see  Clinical Review…StrokeCognitive Deficits – Occupational Therapy  ; CINAHL Topic ID Number

other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies

Clinicians should follow the guidelines of their clinic/hospital and what is ordered by the patient’s physician. The summary presented below is meant to serve as a guide, not to replace orders from a physician or a clinic’s specific protocols

Low-intensity  rehabilitation (e.g., passive ROM) should begin once the patient is medically stable ; early mobilization can prevent or lessen harmful effects of deconditioning and secondary impairments(9)

Early assessment of the patient’s environment (e.g., the hospital room) as well as identification and modification of barriers (e.g., modifying the call bell for improved access to nursing care) might help motivate the patient for rehabilitation(13)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: The occupational therapist (OT) must consider the patient’s risk factors and deficits to determine if the patient is an appropriate candidate for CIMT; CIMT is an intensive therapy and is not appropriate for all survivors of stroke(3) CIMT and mCIMT have demonstrated that they can be effective treatments for patients with mild-moderate  impairment of the upper and lower extremity following stroke(47,51)
assessment plan of care.rule out: The patient’s medical team will rule out TIA as well as migraine, seizure, brain tumor, and other neurologic disorders (such as multiple sclerosis) prior to diagnosing stroke(1,2)
prognosis: The degree to which patients will recover from stroke varies significantly according to severity of initial deficits, etiology of the stroke, and concurrent medical and/or surgical complications(1)
Initially (within the first few weeks), improvements occur rapidly due to spontaneous recovery(3,9)

Later recovery is thought to result from structural and functional reorganization within the brain(3) –CIMT is one type of therapy that has been repeatedly linked to cortical reorganization as seen in fMRI and transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) studies(4,9,26)

In a study conducted in Nigeria with 30 survivors of stroke, researchers found that age, sex, and handedness/affected side did not significantly influence the duration of adherence to restraint use in a 3-week  CIMT program. Researchers did note that duration of adherence to restraint use was significantly longer in the group of participants classified as having middle socioeconomic status (SES) versus low SES. Researchers recommended consideration of SES when deciding whether to implement CIMT(27)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Referral to physical therapy if the patient has difficulty with gait, ambulation, transfers, or weight-bearing(2,9) Referral to speech therapy if the patient presents with speech, language, cognitive, or swallowing problems(2,9) Referral to a physiatrist to manage the patient’s rehabilitation team Referral to neuropsychology for significant cognitive impairment(2,9) Referral to ophthalmology or neuro-ophthalmology  for assessment and treatment of visual disturbances after stroke(9) Referral to dietician if the patient has any feeding or swallowing difficulties and might be at risk for malnutrition; patient might require supplements or supplemental feedings(9) Referral to recreational or vocational therapist for returning to activities of leisure and employment(9) Referral to audiology if the patient appears to have a hearing impairment Referral to psychiatry, psychology, or social work if patient appears depressed or anxious, is having difficulty coping with stroke/disability, and/or might benefit from assistance with issues such as facility placement(2,9)
other considerations: Issues that limit the application of CIMT in clinical practice include poor compliance with restraint schedule, concerns for patient safety and limited independence while unaffected limb is restrained, lack of facility resources to provide the level of intense training recommended in CIMT research studies, and difficulty receiving reimbursement from insurance companies for CIMT(3,5)

CARE-CITE  is a program developed to provide support to care providers and assist them in effectively helping their loved ones complete CIMT. Authors of a study found that this type of program allows for collaboration between rehabilitation professionals and care providers. It is a feasible and beneficial intervention that engages the support of care providers without increasing family conflict during the stroke recovery process(48)
treatment summary: CIMT involves restraining the unaffected (or less-affected)  upper extremity 90% of waking hours over the course of 2–6 weeks while performing daily 6-hour  training sessions with the affected upper extremity(3)  –The choice of activities and specific interventions is at the discretion of the treating therapist(4) –Tasks should be selected to address the specific motor deficits of the patient(4) –Tasks and movements that are motivating to the patient should be utilized to increase the likelihood of compliance and improvement(4)

Poor compliance with CIMT programs led to the development of mCIMT. mCIMT shortens the training sessions to 30 minutes a day, 3 times a week and reduces the restraint time of the nonaffected extremity to ˂ 6 hours per day(45)
CIMT was originally developed for the upper extremity, but it is now being used and studied for the lower extremity

More variations to CIMT programs continue to develop and be researched. However, most share four components: intensive daily treatment over consecutive days, supervised motor training following techniques known as shaping, behavioral strategies to encourage use of the affected limb in daily activities (referred to as a transfer package), and strategies to remind patients to use the affected limb more and restrain the unaffected limb. For lower extremity programs,the last component, limb restraint, is often not included. Encouraging use of the affected limb is part of the program, but often it is difficult to restrain the lower extremity. Whether to restrain the lower extremity is often determined by individual therapists or study protocols(49)

Canadian Best Practice Stroke Recommendations on stroke rehabilitation found early-level  A and late-level  A evidence for traditional CIMT or mCIMT. They recommend that it be used with patients who demonstrate at least 20° of active wrist extension and 10° of active finger extension and have minimal sensory and/or cognitive deficits(50)

Guidelines from the American Heart Association/American Stroke Association on stroke rehabilitationstate that CIMT has been demonstrated to improve upper extremity function, participation, and QOL in patients who have a baseline ability to control wrist and finger extension as compared to usual care. They also found similar results between traditional CIMT programs and mCIMT programs(51)

The Extremity Constraint Induced Therapy Evaluation (EXCITE) trial, conducted in the United States, was the first national multicenter, prospective, single-blind,  randomized clinical trial to systematically test the effects of CIMT in adult survivors of stroke in the subacute to chronic stage(18,21,22) –Total of 222 participants with mild-moderate  impairments from stroke in the 3- to 9-month  period prior to beginning therapy; 106 subjects in the treatment group and 116 in the control group(18,21,22) -Patients in the treatment group received 2 weeks of CIMT -Patients in the control group received 2 weeks of traditional therapy(21) –Researchers found that CIMT produced significant improvements in motor function, functional usage of the affected arm, and QOL; also, these improvements were found to persist for at least 2 years(18,22) –In a retrospective study conducted in South Korea, researchers analyzed the EXCITE trial data to determine which factors were most predictive of a clinically meaningful outcome with CIMT(18) -The factors found to be most predictive of a clinically meaningful outcome immediately post treatment were initial MAL Quality of Movement score of ≥ 2 or a WMFT score of ≤ 5 seconds (i.e., better pretreatment motor function) -The factors found to be most predictive of a long-term  clinically meaningful outcome were pretreatment motor function, pretreatment sensory function, and age

Authors of a systematic review investigated the effectiveness of physical therapy interventions for patients following stroke in low-income  and lower-middle  income countries. For upper limb interventions, CIMT and mirror therapy demonstrated the greatest improvements in functional upper limb outcome measures. For lower limb interventions, motor imagery in addition to usual care demonstrated the greatest improvements in gait and functional outcome measures(41)

Authors of a systematic review and meta-analysis  evaluated the effect of CIMT (both upper limb CIMT and lower limb CIMT) on patient-reported  outcome of health status after stroke(44) –Nine studies were included –CIMT improved patient-reported  outcome of health status at follow-up,  but the results were not statistically significant compared to the control groups. CIMT significantly improve motor function and quantity and quality of movement compared to the control groups

Authors of a 2014 Cochrane review of the interventions for improving upper limb function after stroke found moderate-quality  evidence to support CIMT, but cautioned that additional research is needed to determine the relative effectiveness of different upper extremity interventions that are currently being used for stroke rehabilitation(34)

Authors of a meta-analysis  that included 23 trials (from 3,842 records that were screened) found a small but significant effect on arm motor function immediately after CIMT in the subacute and chronic group and a moderate effect on arm motor activity both immediately and 3–6 months post CIMT. The authors were not able to draw conclusions about the impact of CIMT on ability to perform ADLs or IADLs(33)

Authors of a systematic review with meta-analysis  compared CIMT with dose-matched  interventions for upper limb dysfunction in adult survivors of stroke and found that CIMT produced greater improvements than other, traditional occupational therapy interventions(29) –Authors included 22 studies for quantitative synthesis –CIMT led to superior outcomes on performance-based  measures of upper limb motor capacity, upper limb ability, comprehensive function, and self-report  measurements of upper limb use and quality of movement compared to other interventions for the upper limb after stroke

Authors of a study (N = 36) aimed to determine if a group therapy setting of mCIMT for the upper extremity improves function and ability to perform ADLs in patients following stroke(46) –All patients received therapy for 3 hours a day for 10 consecutive days. They were either placed in a group for the therapy or individually treated. At the end of each session, both groups were given 5 specific tasks to perform at home while wearing a mitt to continue to promote use of the affected side –Outcome measures included the MAL and the ARAT –Both groups improved in function and in the use of the affected upper limb, but those participating in the group therapy had greater increases. These improvements were also maintained at 6 months post intervention –Group therapy may be more beneficial because the group setting provides patients with a sense of security, affection, belonging, and self-esteem.  It also may be more feasible, as it can increase access to rehabilitation, optimize therapists’ time, and be more cost-effective

Authors of a study (N = 20) compared the effectiveness of voluntary restraint of upper extremity to mCIMT in patients with chronic stroke. The intervention period was 5 days a week for 4 weeks(45) –V oluntary restraint group: 1 hour of hand function training in each session while being asked to voluntarily restrain unaffected hand. Patients were asked to voluntarily restrain the unaffected hand for 3 hours per day –mCIMT group: 1 hour of hand function training in each session with a hand mitt placed on unaffected hand. Patients were to wear the hand mitt for 3 hours per day –Outcome measures included Wolf Motor Function Test, MAL, amount of use, and quality of movement. Both groups improved significantly in all hand function measures. There was no significant difference between groups –The authors concluded that voluntary restraint can be an effective method for mCIMT and can improve hand function in patients following stroke. It may be a safer alternative for certain patients

Authors of an RCT (N = 30) compared functional electrical stimulation (FES) with task-oriented  therapy and FES with mCIMT to improve hand function in patients following a stroke(43) –Patients were divided into three groups: FES with task-oriented  therapy, FES with mCIMT, and FES with usual care (control). All patients completed sessions 5 days a week for 6 weeks –FES with task-oriented  therapy group participated in 30 minutes of FES, 30 minutes of task-oriented  training, and 30 minutes of usual physical therapy care for each session –FES with mCIMT group participated in 30 minutes of FES, 30 minutes of mCIMT, and 30 minutes of usual physical therapy care for each session. The patients’ unaffected hand and wrist were place in mitts for 6 hours of the day when they frequently would use their hand/wrist, 5 days a week –FES with usual care group participated in a combination of FES and physical therapy exercises for 60 minutes a session –There was a significant improvement in hand function as measured by the ARAT and grip strength in all three groups. There was a greater improvement in the FES with task-oriented  therapy group and FES with mCIMT group compared to the control group

In a pilot quasi-randomized  controlled trial conducted in Japan with 21 patients with hemiparesis in the chronic stage of stroke, researchers found that the use of a transfer package improved the carryover of therapeutic gains of CIMT to real-world activities(25) –Study took place over the course of 10 consecutive weekdays; the control group received 5 hours of CIMT per day and the experimental group received 4.5 hours of CIMT as well as 30 minutes of the transfer package daily –The transfer package is an additional protocol first described in another study that was designed to increase carryover of CIMT gains into real-world  tasks. In this study, the transfer protocol involved having the patients agree to use their  affected arm for specific ADLs (up to 10 per patient) outside of the therapy room. Each patient in the transfer package group had a home diary that was to be used to track affected arm use for these ADLs as well as specific problem-solving training in how to use assistive devices to increase use of the affected arm in ADLs –Outcomes were measured with the FMA and the Amount of Use scale of the MAL immediately before and after intervention as well as 6 months post intervention -Participants in the experimental group demonstrated similar, but slightly greater, improvements on both outcome measures immediately postintervention -Outcome measures after 6 months showed that participants in the control group maintained the gains made in therapy. Participants in the experimental group showed continued improvements in arm function, and scores on both outcome measures were significantly better for the experimental, transfer package group

Researchers who conducted an RCT in the United States concluded that use of a transfer package in addition to CIMT led to significantly better carryover of functional upper extremity skills than CIMT alone(30) –Forty participants with upper-extremity  paresis poststroke were divided into four groups (two included a transfer package, two had no transfer package); all groups involved constraint of the unaffected limb during treatment sessions –All participants participated in 3.5 hours of therapy per day; members of the transfer package groups were instructed to wear the heavily padded constraint mitt on their less-affected  arm for a target of 90% of all waking hours, and those without transfer package used the mitt only during training sessions –Researchers found that the use of a transfer package, regardless of the specific tasks performed in therapy sessions, resulted in significantly larger functional gains with respect to arm use. Researchers used the MAL to assess real-world treatment affects; scores on the MAL posttreatment were 2.4 times higher in the groups that received a transfer package than in the groups that did not. Gains on the MAL were maintained by the transfer package group in a follow-up assessment 1year postintervention

In a double-blind  RCT in Korea, researchers concluded that mCIMT performed 5 days per week for 4 weeks is more effective when used in conjunction with trunk restraint in patients with subacute stroke. Trunk restraint was utilized to prevent compensatory movements of the trunk, thereby encouraging the patient to increase the use of the affected extremity during mCIMT treatment(36)

Researchers who conducted an RCT concluded that CIMT and a motor relearning program (MRP) are both effective in improving upper-extremity  function in patients with subacute hemiparesis; however, CIMT was more effective(35) –Based on a study in India including 45 subacute hemiparetic patients who were randomized into one of two groups, CIMT or MRP –Both groups received training for 14 days -In the CIMT group, the unaffected extremity was constrained for 80% of working hours; the affected side was treated with 3 hours of task-oriented functional activities -MRP treatment was based on kinematic task analysis and identification of the deficiency of the task. The missing component was initially the focus of the training; the secondary step was to incorporate the practiced missing component into the task. The MRP group focused on upper extremity functional training for 30 minutes daily –Outcome measures included the 9-hole  peg test, MAL, and Fugl-Meyer –Significant improvement was found in both groups, evidenced by the MAL and the Fugl-Meyer.  The CIMT group demonstrated better improvement on the MAL. Based on the Fugl-Meyer,  no significant differences were found between groups. No significant differences were found on the 9-hole  peg test scores in either group

Authors of a study conducted in the Netherlands concluded that mCIMT is more beneficial for improving upper limb capacity compared to usual care in patients who are considered to have a “favorable” prognosis following an ischemic stroke(39) –Fifty-eight  patients with a favorable prognosis were randomized to a 3-week  intervention of either mCIMT or usual-care-only  group –Results at the end of this study suggest that patients with a favorable prognosis would significantly benefit from the mCIMT program

Authors of a study conducted in South Korea suggest that virtual-reality  training combined with mCIMT can be an effective treatment option for improving upper extremity function in patients who have had an acute stroke(40)

Authors of a case study evaluated the effectiveness of a lower extremity CIMT program. A56-year-old  woman with chronic stroke and gait dysfunction participated in a lower extremity CIMT program for 3.5 hours a day for 10 consecutive weekdays(49)  –Each day 3 hours were dedicated to motor training and 30 minutes to transfer package activities with a therapist. The tasks picked as transfer activities were practiced 10 times each for 30–45  seconds –In this CIMT protocol the patient’s unaffected lower extremity was not restrained but instead she was instructed to focus all her attention on increasing use and improving the movement of her affected lower extremity –All outcome measures had positive changes. All scores on the lower extremity MAL increased. There were pre and post improvements in her gait speed, endurance, balance, level of assistance, perceived quality of movement, and confidence performing ADLs

Authors of a study protocol have outlined an RCT to investigate two different protocols of lower limb CIMT following stroke. Patients will be placed into 1 of 2 groups. The first group of patients will complete 600 repetitions of a task per day, 5 days a week for 4 weeks. The second group will perform task practice for 3 hours a day for 5 days a week for 4 weeks. Both groups will be asked to restrict the use of the unaffected limb during the training(42)

Authors of a study (N = 30) investigated the efficacy of mCIMT on QOL and muscle strength for the lower extremityin patients following stroke. All patients received neurodevelopmental therapy sessions for 60 minutes, 3 times per week for 4 weeks. Then half of the patients continued this therapy for 2 weeks while the other half started mCIMT sessions for 120 minutes, 5 times per week for 2 weeks(47) –Strength and QOL improved for both groups, but paretic lower limb strength increased more in the mCIMT group –mCIMT for a paretic lower limb can be an effective supportive method to improve QOL and muscle strength . outcomes and related measures: Improved upper extremity motor function and overall functional status, ADLs/IADLs–WMFT was specifically designed to be sensitive to motor functioning of patients with mild-moderate  stroke as well as toexamine the effects of CIMT(4,16)–MAL was developed to measure the improvement of learned nonuse as well as the use of the impaired upper extremity inADLs poststroke(4,16)–ABILHAND is a questionnaire designed for measuring outcomes of therapy for the upper extremity(16)–AMAT and ARAT have been used to document outcomes for CIMT in research studies(4)
Improved upper extremity strength and ROM–MMT–Dynamometry

maintenance or prevention: Prevention of stroke focuses on addressing modifiable risk factors,(8) including cessation of cigarette smoking(2,10) controlling hypertension, diabetes, heart disease, and/or hyperlipidemia with appropriate medications(2) maintaining a healthy weight(1,2,10) increasing physical activity(2,10) seeking treatment for alcohol and/or drug abuse(2,10) eating a healthy diet that is low in fat(2,10)
The role of OTs in helping to prevent secondary strokes in their patients includes health promotion and disease prevention through education about the modification of the above risk factors(24)
